org.jooby

Interface Route.Filter

  • All Known Subinterfaces:
    Route.After, Route.Before, Route.Complete, Route.Handler, Route.MethodHandler, Route.OneArgHandler, Route.ZeroArgHandler, Sse.Handler, Sse.Handler1
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AssetHandler, CorsHandler, CsrfHandler, HealthCheckHandler, InstrumentedHandler, MetricHandler, PingHandler, PrometheusHandler, RequestLogger, SSIHandler, ThreadDumpHandler, TimedHandler
    Enclosing interface:
    Route 

    public static interface Route.Filter
    The most advanced route handler which let you decided if the next route handler in the chain can be executed or not. Example of filters are:

    Auth handler example: 

       String token = req.header("token").value();
   if (token != null) {
     // validate token...
     if (valid(token)) {
       chain.next(req, rsp);
     }
   } else {
     rsp.status(403);
   }

    Logging/Around handler example: 

       long start = System.currentTimeMillis();
   chain.next(req, rsp);
   long end = System.currentTimeMillis();
   log.info("Request: {} took {}ms", req.path(), end - start);
    NOTE: Don't forget to call Route.Chain.next(Request, Response) if next route handler need to be executed.
    Since:
    0.1.0
    Author:
    edgar

    • Method Summary

      All Methods  Instance Methods  Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void handle(Request req, Response rsp, Route.Chain chain)
      The handle method of the Filter is called by the server each time a request/response pair is passed through the chain due to a client request for a resource at the end of the chain.

    • Method Detail

      • handle

        void handle(Request req,
            Response rsp,
            Route.Chain chain)
     throws Throwable
        The handle method of the Filter is called by the server each time a request/response pair is passed through the chain due to a client request for a resource at the end of the chain. The Route.Chain passed in to this method allows the Filter to pass on the request and response to the next entity in the chain.

        A typical implementation of this method would follow the following pattern:

        • Examine the request
        • Optionally wrap the request object with a custom implementation to filter content or headers for input filtering
        • Optionally wrap the response object with a custom implementation to filter content or headers for output filtering
          • Either invoke the next entity in the chain using the Route.Chain object (chain.next(req, rsp)),
          • or not pass on the request/response pair to the next entity in the filter chain to block the request processing
        • Directly set headers on the response after invocation of the next entity in the filter chain.
        Parameters:
        req - A HTTP request.
        rsp - A HTTP response.
        chain - A route chain.
        Throws:
        Throwable - If something goes wrong.
